<title level="1" right="Focus 4" pfs="Standard">[Precious Metals](/Spells.aspx?ID=440)</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=159" />
<trait label="Cleric" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=26" />
<trait label="Transmutation" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=157" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

<row gap="tiny">**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 395 <sup>4.0</sup></row>

**Domain**
[Wealth](/Domains.aspx?ID=36)

<row gap="medium">

<row gap="tiny">
<row>**Cast**</row>
<row><actions string="Single Action" /></row>
<row>[material](/Rules.aspx?ID=282)</row>
</row>

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Range** touch

**Target** 1 metal weapon, up to 10 pieces of metal or metal-tipped ammunition, 1 suit of metal armor, or up to 1 bulk of metal material (such as coins)
</row>

<row gap="medium">

**Duration** 1 minute
</row>

</column>

---

Your deity blesses base metals to transform them into precious materials. The target item transforms from its normal metal into [cold iron](/Equipment.aspx?ID=272), copper, gold, iron, [silver](/Equipment.aspx?ID=277), or steel. An item transmuted in this way deals damage according to its new material. For example, a steel sword transmuted to cold iron would deal additional damage to a creature with a weakness to cold iron.

 This change is clearly magical and temporary, so the item's monetary value doesn't change; you couldn't transmute copper coins to gold and use those coins to purchase something or as a cost for a spell.

---
**Heightened (8th)** Add [adamantine](/Equipment.aspx?ID=271) and [mithral](/Equipment.aspx?ID=275) to the list of metals you can transform the item into.
